quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You don't want to walk into the gym on day one and try and deadlift 300 pounds. So when someone comes to me and they're a first time entrepreneur and they say, "I'm going to make the next great AI company," I think that is the equivalent.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for right-sizing your first startup ambition and choosing a challenge level you can realistically execute.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Fish where the fish are.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: A simple heuristic for focusing on markets/opportunities with proven demand rather than forcing a hard, uncertain bet.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The biggest mistakes I've made have been going into business models where other people have repeatedly failed and thinking, I can do this better.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Actionable warning against overconfidence—avoid business models with a long track record of failure unless you have a truly unique edge.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It's like having the world's most reliable employee who costs $200 a month and works 24/7. So many knowledge work jobs are going to change massively. I think the fundamental question is, do all jobs just become a single prompt?
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A concrete framing of AI’s cost/availability and a provocative question that helps practitioners rethink workflows around prompting and automation.

quotes.topic_title: Finding startup ideas by avoiding crowded markets
quotes.text: I think a mistake a lot of people make is they choose something that everybody is interested in.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A contrarian heuristic for idea selection: avoid markets that attract universal interest because they tend to be overcrowded.

quotes.topic_title: Finding startup ideas by avoiding crowded markets
quotes.text: But on the flip side, almost nobody wakes up every morning and says, "You know what? I'd love to start a funeral home," or "I would like to start a pest control business," or "I should start software that helps people fill out forms for the government."
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Concrete examples of “unsexy” niches that may have less competition and better economics than glamorous ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Finding startup ideas by avoiding crowded markets
quotes.text: "Fish where the fish are."
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for focusing effort where opportunity is abundant rather than where competition is densest.

quotes.topic_title: Finding startup ideas by avoiding crowded markets
quotes.text: You actually want to walk off into the forest and find a small fishing hole with lots of fish and very little competition.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A practical strategy for finding startup ideas: seek smaller, under-contested markets with clear demand.

quotes.topic_title: Finding startup ideas by avoiding crowded markets
quotes.text: I think that's probably the most important thing in business is actually to find those niches where you can actually make real money because competition equals lower margin.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Links market selection to unit economics: fewer competitors generally means higher margins and easier differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Start small to build entrepreneurial “reps”
quotes.text: I don't necessarily think it has to be something that is small forever, but it has to be something that like I think about if you're a first time entrepreneur or a student or something, you don't want to walk into the gym on day one and try and deadlift 300 pounds.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for choosing appropriately scoped first businesses to build skill and confidence.

quotes.topic_title: Start small to build entrepreneurial “reps”
quotes.text: I think you really want to take the baby weights and start slowly building your muscle.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Actionable advice to deliberately start with simpler ventures to accumulate entrepreneurial “reps.”

quotes.topic_title: Start small to build entrepreneurial “reps”
quotes.text: I was so lucky because the first business I ever started my web design agency, which became Metalab, that was so easy and it worked immediately because all I had to do was know how to build websites and be able to talk to potential customers.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how picking a straightforward business model can create early momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Start small to build entrepreneurial “reps”
quotes.text: And because of that, I got immediate positive feedback and I built my own narrative. And my narrative was, "I'm good at business, I can do this, keep going."
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Highlights the compounding effect of early wins on founder psychology and persistence.

quotes.topic_title: Start small to build entrepreneurial “reps”
quotes.text: And I just think it's so critical that people choose a business where they get that initial win.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A clear selection criterion founders can apply when evaluating what to start first.

quotes.topic_title: Avoid building a job: scale and delegation
quotes.text: Look, if this gets to scale, you'll never touch a pressure washer unless you want to.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Reframes “dirty work” businesses as attractive if you scale enough to delegate the unpleasant tasks.

quotes.topic_title: Avoid building a job: scale and delegation
quotes.text: There's a big difference between a business and a job.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A simple mental model for evaluating whether an idea will trap you in day-to-day labor or become an asset.

quotes.topic_title: Avoid building a job: scale and delegation
quotes.text: I think if you could start a pressure washing business where you're the only employee, yeah, that's a job, but if you can get to a scale where you can drive 10 leads a day, then you don't have to do any of the pressure washing and you just do what you love.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Gives a concrete scaling threshold (lead volume) that enables delegation and role specialization.

quotes.topic_title: Avoid building a job: scale and delegation
quotes.text: And I think they really need to lean into what I call lazy leadership, which is how do I get away from the things I hate as quickly as humanly possible? How do I be Teflon for tasks?
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable framework for aggressively delegating or eliminating disliked work.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing software vs physical businesses via unfair advantage
quotes.text: I think the question is, what's your unfair advantage and what are you great at?
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A simple idea-selection filter: start by identifying the specific strengths that give you an edge before choosing software vs. physical businesses.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing software vs physical businesses via unfair advantage
quotes.text: And so ultimately my highest and best use my superpower was sales. And so that can be applied to anything, anything where you need to go out and you need to sell a customer.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A transferable-skill lens for picking businesses: choose arenas where your core advantage (e.g., sales) compounds regardless of industry.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing software vs physical businesses via unfair advantage
quotes.text: But it's really just a job for a few different people and we can't make any money at it, but I've been noticing that there's all these vendors that service the restaurant and those guys are making a killing.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Counterintuitive opportunity-spotting: the “boring” adjacent suppliers to a passion industry can be far more profitable than the glamorous core business.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing software vs physical businesses via unfair advantage
quotes.text: So I follow my passions and spend a long time learning different industries and then I find the profitable niche within.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology: use passion to sustain deep learning, then deliberately search for the monetizable wedge inside that domain.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing software vs physical businesses via unfair advantage
quotes.text: Well, if you just pivot that idea just ever so slightly, and instead of doing restaurants, you did realtors or wealth managers who have quite a large marketing budget and are used to spending serious money and it only has to work a little bit to make a lot of money for them. Those people, you can charge $5,000 a month.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A concrete pricing/distribution play: keep the same service but switch to customers with higher willingness-to-pay to dramatically increase revenue.

quotes.topic_title: Judging market value: experience, gut, and AI research
quotes.text: I feel like in order to know what problems are valuable to solve, you kind of need to have valuable problems.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A counterintuitive framing that market judgment is learned through exposure to real, high-value problems—not just ideation.

quotes.topic_title: Judging market value: experience, gut, and AI research
quotes.text: I didn't understand how little people were actually willing to pay. I didn't have a enough life experience to go, "Yes, that's actually a worthwhile opportunity."
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Highlights a practical failure mode for founders: mispricing willingness-to-pay due to lack of domain and customer reality.

quotes.topic_title: Judging market value: experience, gut, and AI research
quotes.text: So my example of a realtor selling a house, because I've studied that industry, I know that a realtor can make like 20 to $50,000 selling a single house.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing how understanding customer economics anchors what they can rationally pay for solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Judging market value: experience, gut, and AI research
quotes.text: I mean, I think all entrepreneurs are so lucky now to be able to go into Claude or ChatGPT and just say, "Hey, I'm thinking about starting a Botox clinic. Can you break down the numbers? Is this a good business? What's hard about it? What is the regulatory moat? What would my payroll look like?"
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: An actionable methodology: use LLMs to pre-model unit economics, constraints, and moats before committing to an idea.

quotes.topic_title: Judging market value: experience, gut, and AI research
quotes.text: I didn't have any of that and so I started so many incredibly stupid businesses, but I think there's no excuse at this point. You should be able to do it with AI.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A blunt, memorable push to operationalize AI as due diligence to avoid preventable early-stage mistakes.

quotes.topic_title: Boring businesses and why flashy ideas fail
quotes.text: We made the mistake that so many entrepreneurs make, which is to go after an industry that everybody goes after just like cafes.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A cautionary heuristic: avoid overcrowded, obvious categories where competition is structurally intense.

quotes.topic_title: Boring businesses and why flashy ideas fail
quotes.text: It was all my own money, poured $10 million, lit it on fire trying to compete with Asana because I didn't understand how the business world worked really as they had raised hundreds of millions of dollars and they were run by the co-founder of Facebook and it was a little bit like, I'm Fiji and I'm deciding I'm going to invade the United States in retrospect, just completely silly.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A vivid mental model for mismatched competition: bootstrapping against massively funded incumbents can be unwinnable regardless of effort.

quotes.topic_title: Boring businesses and why flashy ideas fail
quotes.text: They were making $30 million a year and all they did was help people fill out forms to get government assistance in certain programs.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how “boring” problem areas can hide large, profitable businesses with less hype-driven competition.

quotes.topic_title: Boring businesses and why flashy ideas fail
quotes.text: They just have software that fills out the forms for you and it says, look, you're going to get $20,000 as a grant, pay us a thousand bucks, and that is such a boring, nobody wakes up and goes, "I want to make form filling software," but I think they would if they could make 20 million a year
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A counterintuitive pricing/value framing: monetize painful bureaucracy by taking a small cut of a clear, high-ROI outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding “graveyard” business models and false confidence
quotes.text: the biggest mistakes I've made business-wise have been going into business models where other people have repeatedly failed and thinking, I can do this better.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A simple filter for idea selection: avoid “graveyard” models where many capable people have already failed.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding “graveyard” business models and false confidence
quotes.text: We realized that we didn't know anything about business compared to someone who runs a pizzeria.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A humbling reminder that operationally complex small businesses can demand deeper expertise than many tech founders assume.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding “graveyard” business models and false confidence
quotes.text: It's like you can't take a brilliant management team and change a bad business model. Ultimately the business model wins.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A core mental model: management quality can’t reliably overcome structurally weak unit economics.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding “graveyard” business models and false confidence
quotes.text: would it be easier to start Instacart, Amazon or Coupang or would it be easier to start an enterprise SaaS software company? Definitely the enterprise SaaS software company.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A practical comparison for founders: choose business models with fewer operational dependencies and lower execution risk.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding “graveyard” business models and false confidence
quotes.text: it goes back to my gym analogy of if you're going to deadlift 300 pounds, trained for 15 years, you should have already had three startups and they should have worked and you've really built up the reps.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A “reps before weight” framework for matching ambition to experience and earned capability.

quotes.topic_title: Bootstrapping vs venture: goals, competition, and scale
quotes.text: Well, I think it's just not true that a "lifestyle" or bootstrap business can't get huge. I mean, we bootstrapped the entire business and now across all of our companies we do almost $300 million in revenue.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Counters the common belief that bootstrapped companies can’t scale, backed by a concrete revenue data point.

quotes.topic_title: Bootstrapping vs venture: goals, competition, and scale
quotes.text: And I think that the only difference between what we do and what a venture capitalist does is the level of tolerance of burning money on fire.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A memorable mental model reframing bootstrapping vs. venture as primarily a capital-burning tolerance difference.

quotes.topic_title: Bootstrapping vs venture: goals, competition, and scale
quotes.text: So I think the decision ultimately comes down to how hairy do you want your big, hairy, audacious goal to be?
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Provides a practical decision criterion for choosing between venture-scale ambitions and a bootstrapped path.

quotes.topic_title: Bootstrapping vs venture: goals, competition, and scale
quotes.text: If the goal is the founder has an incredible life, probably has three houses, flies all over the place, does whatever he wants, has recurring revenue and he gets to work with headphones on building beautiful piece of software that people love, then I think he's won.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Redefines “winning” as lifestyle and autonomy rather than maximum market share, challenging conventional startup success metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Bootstrapping vs venture: goals, competition, and scale
quotes.text: So it's just not that exciting to them, which again, going back to fish where the fish are, you don't want to be fighting against the commercial fishermen. If you just want to have a little business where you get enough fish to feed your family and your village or whatever, find the other fishing hole. Don't go where the trawlers are.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Actionable competitive strategy: pick markets VCs ignore to avoid competing with heavily capitalized players.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great business: moats and acquisition criteria
quotes.text: So when I'm buying a business, what I'm really looking for is something that I can't mess up.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A simple acquisition filter: prioritize businesses resilient enough that even imperfect ownership won’t break them.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great business: moats and acquisition criteria
quotes.text: when Tiny buys a company, we generally just leave them alone. If they already have management in place, we say nothing changes, no one should know that we've even bought them.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A post-acquisition operating principle: minimize integration and preserve what’s already working.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great business: moats and acquisition criteria
quotes.text: And so I'm really looking for what Warren Buffett would call a moat.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Introduces the core mental model guiding what “great businesses” look like in practice.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great business: moats and acquisition criteria
quotes.text: So typically we're looking for a community that's gotten so big where people don't want to go elsewhere.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A concrete way to evaluate network effects: user lock-in driven by community scale rather than features.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great business: moats and acquisition criteria
quotes.text: There's another moat, which is high switching costs, which I don't really like because it's not really very consumer friendly, but an example might be Salesforce where no one wants to, they've spent years and they've done all the implementation and trained everyone on it, and it's kind of the standard, everybody hates it, but ripping it out and switching is such a pain in the that they just won't bother.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A contrarian take on a common moat: switching costs can create durable businesses even when customers dislike the product.

quotes.topic_title: Serato acquisition and passion-driven pattern recognition
quotes.text: We bought Serato. Serato is the largest DJ software company in the world.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A concrete example of an acquisition target with clear category leadership, useful for thinking about buying market leaders rather than speculative bets.

quotes.topic_title: Serato acquisition and passion-driven pattern recognition
quotes.text: I used to DJ so I was aware of them and it was one of those moments we talked about earlier where I understood the business.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Highlights the practical advantage of domain experience for faster, higher-conviction evaluation of opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Serato acquisition and passion-driven pattern recognition
quotes.text: They had a really interesting mode of this huge passionate user base and deep hardware integration.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A simple moat framework practitioners can apply: look for passionate users plus tight integration that raises switching costs.

quotes.topic_title: Serato acquisition and passion-driven pattern recognition
quotes.text: And I also love DJing and I was able to analyze the business and luck comes to the prepared mind and it worked out.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Actionable mental model: passion + preparation increases the odds of “lucky” outcomes in dealmaking and investing.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring and people: “no problems, only people problems”
quotes.text: My business partner, Chris, has a really great quote. He says, "There are no problems. There is only people problems."
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A simple management framework that reframes most business issues as hiring/people issues.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring and people: “no problems, only people problems”
quotes.text: So I'd say I spend probably 20% of my time just trying to make sure we're filtering people very carefully and ensuring we're working with people that we enjoy.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A concrete prioritization signal: invest significant time upfront in screening to avoid downstream people problems.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring and people: “no problems, only people problems”
quotes.text: I've just found that the biggest mistake I made in my early career was I would hire people because I liked them on gut and I would think that I could change them.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Warns against gut-based hiring and the common trap of believing you can “fix” someone after hiring.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring and people: “no problems, only people problems”
quotes.text: And the kind of heuristic I have is if I ever think, should I fire this person even once, I should fire them immediately.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A decisive firing heuristic practitioners can apply to reduce prolonged team drag and uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring and people: “no problems, only people problems”
quotes.text: So I'd say the lesson really is hire for what you need. Don't hire just for potential, which is counter to what a lot of people say.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A contrarian hiring principle that challenges the popular “hire for potential and coach” approach.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring CEOs: alignment, autonomy, and the ‘hammer’ problem
quotes.text: And there's this great saying, "To a man with a hammer, everything looks like a nail."
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why leaders default to the strategies they already know, even when the business needs something else.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring CEOs: alignment, autonomy, and the ‘hammer’ problem
quotes.text: And I've just found that hiring CEOs is like they're an elephant and you're the rider.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A vivid framework for CEO autonomy: their instincts and momentum dominate, and you can’t reliably steer them through directives.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring CEOs: alignment, autonomy, and the ‘hammer’ problem
quotes.text: And so listening incredibly carefully to people's words and their experiences, because generally people will do the thing they tell you.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: Actionable hiring advice: treat what candidates emphasize as a predictor of what they’ll actually execute once in the role.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring CEOs: alignment, autonomy, and the ‘hammer’ problem
quotes.text: So what I look for when I interview a CEO now, I want to be nodding along. I want to go, that's exactly what I would do or that's way smarter than my idea. And then I just leave them alone because I've found that anytime I try and pull them in a certain direction or coach them or whatever, it just doesn't work.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A practical methodology for CEO selection and management: hire for aligned instincts, then give full autonomy instead of trying to coach directionally.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring CEOs: alignment, autonomy, and the ‘hammer’ problem
quotes.text: Well, I've also found people will shoot themselves in the foot. If I tell them an idea in a board meeting and I say, "I really need you to try this," it never works because usually they sandbag it, right? They don't really put their heart into it or they're just placating me and they don't want it to work. They want their idea to work. And so I've learned not to do that.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation about leadership: pushing your own ideas can backfire because execution quality drops when the owner isn’t bought in.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: 76% of people believe that AI can benefit their role, but over 50% of people struggle to know when to use it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete data point highlighting that the main barrier to AI adoption is knowing when to apply it, not believing in its value.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Enter Miro's innovation Workspace, an intelligent platform that brings people and AI together in a shared space to get great work done.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical collaboration model: integrate AI directly into the team’s shared workspace rather than treating it as a separate tool.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Teams can work with Miro AI to turn unstructured data like sticky notes or screenshots into usable diagrams, product briefs, data tables, and prototypes in minutes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific, actionable workflow example for converting messy inputs into structured artifacts quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The work you're already doing in Miro's canvas is the prompt.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reduces prompting friction by treating existing work as the input to AI.

quotes.topic_title: AI workflows with Lindy: automating email and calendar
quotes.text: So it's very simple. You might say, "When I get an email in the Gmail API, I want to add an AI agent that reads the email and labels it based on that."
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A concrete, reusable pattern for turning inbox events into automated AI actions via workflow triggers.

quotes.topic_title: AI workflows with Lindy: automating email and calendar
quotes.text: So I have just basically tried to take every single thing a human could do in my inbox and automate it with Lindy.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A clear methodology: systematically replace assistant-like inbox tasks with automation rather than ad-hoc AI usage.

quotes.topic_title: AI workflows with Lindy: automating email and calendar
quotes.text: So basically emails come in and the first agent says, does Andrew even need to see this? Let's say you're in a thread and you've already chimed in and everyone's just saying, cool, that works. I don't need to see that. So just archives that never. So that immediately reduces my email by about 20%.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A practical triage tactic with a specific impact metric (20% reduction) that many teams can implement.

quotes.topic_title: AI workflows with Lindy: automating email and calendar
quotes.text: Then it decides is this something that is time sensitive? Is this something that needs to be dealt with in the next 24 hours? And if so, it labels it in a special 24-hour label.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A simple prioritization system that reduces uncertainty by separating urgent items from the rest of the inbox.

quotes.topic_title: AI workflows with Lindy: automating email and calendar
quotes.text: So it emails me privately and it says, "Hey, Lenny wants to get lunch. Do you want to say yes? Do you want to say yes, but in a few months? Do you want to say no? How do you want to say no?" And it gives me multiple choice.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.context: A high-leverage interaction model: AI proposes response options and the human selects, speeding up decisions while keeping control.
